item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Cyclopropyl for Gem‐Dimethyl: Synthesis and Olfactory Properties of Linear Musks with Cyclopropyl Spacers**
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Fusing the gem‐dimethyl groups into a cyclopropyl ring in the spacer of linear alicyclic musk odorants subtly changes the molecular geometry and polarity of the target structures while the musk odour is retained or even intensified. Aromatic analogues and methylcyclopropane derivatives in contrast were found completely odourless..
Linear musks with cyclopropylmethyl spacers in place of 2‐methylpropyl spacers were designed, synthesised and evaluated olfactorily. Their synthesis commenced from commercially available 1‐(3′, 3′‐dimethylcyclohexyl)ethanone (Herbac) and 3‐methyl benzaldehyde via the corresponding methyl carbinols, Cyclodumol and 1‐(m‐tolyl)ethan‐1‐ol, which were esterified with a protected glycolic acid and then transformed into the corresponding cyclopropyl compound by Tebbe olefination in tandem with Simmons–Smith cyclopropanation. After deprotection and esterification with various short‐chain carboxylic acids, their qualitative olfactory evaluation revealed that fusing the gem‐dimethyl groups into a cyclopropyl ring retains and even intensifies the musk scent. Methylation of the cyclopropyl ring however completely erases not only the distinct musk character but virtually any odour.
item.content:encoded:
Fusing the gem-dimethyl groups into a cyclopropyl ring in the spacer of linear alicyclic musk odorants subtly changes the molecular geometry and polarity of the target structures while the musk odour is retained or even intensified. Aromatic analogues and methylcyclopropane derivatives in contrast were found completely odourless..


Linear musks with cyclopropylmethyl spacers in place of 2-methylpropyl spacers were designed, synthesised and evaluated olfactorily. Their synthesis commenced from commercially available 1-(3′, 3′-dimethylcyclohexyl)ethanone (Herbac) and 3-methyl benzaldehyde via the corresponding methyl carbinols, Cyclodumol and 1-(m-tolyl)ethan-1-ol, which were esterified with a protected glycolic acid and then transformed into the corresponding cyclopropyl compound by Tebbe olefination in tandem with Simmons–Smith cyclopropanation. After deprotection and esterification with various short-chain carboxylic acids, their qualitative olfactory evaluation revealed that fusing the gem-dimethyl groups into a cyclopropyl ring retains and even intensifies the musk scent. Methylation of the cyclopropyl ring however completely erases not only the distinct musk character but virtually any odour.

item.dc:title: Cyclopropyl for Gem‐Dimethyl: Synthesis and Olfactory Properties of Linear Musks with Cyclopropyl Spacers**

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mechanochemical Alkynylation of Isatin with Calcium Carbide: Experimental and Computational Insights into Selectivity
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The reaction of isatin, CaC2, and KOtBu in dimethylsulfoxide has been reported to afford mono‐alkynylation products, whereas we found that under the mechanochemical conditions, the bis‐alkynylation pathway is preferred. In this work, we investigated this transformation experimentally and computationally, both in solution and under mechanochemical conditions, to elucidate the factors governing the selectivity switch.
Alkynylation of isatins with calcium carbide (CaC2) in solution has been reported to selectively yield mono‐alkynylation products (i.e., 3‐ethynyl‐3‐hydroxy‐2‐oxindoles). In this work, we studied the reaction under mechanochemical conditions, finding that upon ball milling, the acetylenic anions [C2]2– present in CaC2 react with isatin, leading preferentially to the bis‐alkynylation addition product [i.e., 3‐ethynyl‐bis(3‐hydroxy‐2‐oxindole)]. Through experimental work and computational mechanistic studies within the framework of density functional theory, we investigated the change in selectivity and identified i) the highly concentrated reaction environment under ball milling and ii) the avoidance of bulk water as conditions that favor the bis‐alkynylation of two isatin molecules with a single [C2]2– fragment. In addition, we found that the reaction occurs through several variants of the same overall mechanism, in which some cationic metal counterions play a relevant role through noncovalent interactions.
item.content:encoded:
The reaction of isatin, CaC2, and KOtBu in dimethylsulfoxide has been reported to afford mono-alkynylation products, whereas we found that under the mechanochemical conditions, the bis-alkynylation pathway is preferred. In this work, we investigated this transformation experimentally and computationally, both in solution and under mechanochemical conditions, to elucidate the factors governing the selectivity switch.


Alkynylation of isatins with calcium carbide (CaC2) in solution has been reported to selectively yield mono-alkynylation products (i.e., 3-ethynyl-3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles). In this work, we studied the reaction under mechanochemical conditions, finding that upon ball milling, the acetylenic anions [C2]2– present in CaC2 react with isatin, leading preferentially to the bis-alkynylation addition product [i.e., 3-ethynyl-bis(3-hydroxy-2-oxindole)]. Through experimental work and computational mechanistic studies within the framework of density functional theory, we investigated the change in selectivity and identified i) the highly concentrated reaction environment under ball milling and ii) the avoidance of bulk water as conditions that favor the bis-alkynylation of two isatin molecules with a single [C2]2– fragment. In addition, we found that the reaction occurs through several variants of the same overall mechanism, in which some cationic metal counterions play a relevant role through noncovalent interactions.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Cortés‐Lobo, Karen J. Ardila‐Fierro, Cacier Z. Hadad, José G. Hernández
item.dc:title: Mechanochemical Alkynylation of Isatin with Calcium Carbide: Experimental and Computational Insights into Selectivity

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Defective NiO Nanoparticles Supported on Nb2O5 for Solid‐Catalyzed Markovnikov‐Selective Hydroboration of Styrenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
NiO deposited on Nb2O5 was an efficient catalyst for Markovnikov‐selective hydroboration of styrenes using B2(pin)2. The catalytically active species were NiO on Nb2O5 and leached Ni species. The coexistence of ZnO served as a redeposition site for the leached Ni species, improving the reusability of the catalyst system.
Markovnikov selective hydroboration of alkenes with an air‐ and moisture‐stable diboron reagent is a more challenging reaction than the anti‐Markovnikov‐selective one. We report that nickel oxide (NiO) supported on niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) efficiently catalyzed the hydroboration of 4‐tert‐butylstyrene, affording a Markovnikov (branched) adduct with excellent selectivity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of the Markovnikov‐selective hydroboration of styrenes with a diboron reagent, bis(pinacolato)diboron, using a solid catalyst. NiO on Nb2O5 contains Ni3+, which is more catalytically active than Ni2+, as a major species in contrast to bulk NiO. However, the catalytic activity decreased upon recycling tests because the Ni species leached from NiO/Nb2O5. The catalytically active species were NiO on Nb2O5 and leached Ni species. To improve the reusability of the catalyst system, NiO/Nb2O5, ZnO was introduced as a redeposition site for the leached Ni species. Ultimately, the desired Markovnikov adduct was obtained in high yield and selectivity using NiO/Nb2O5 in the presence of ZnO (92% yield and 92% selectivity), and catalyst reusability was also improved.
item.content:encoded:

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthetic Strategies to Access Fluorinated Azoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review highlights recent synthetic strategies for introducing fluorine groups (mono‐, di‐, and trifluoromethylation) into 11 major azole classes, identifying research gaps to inform future innovations in materials science, medicinal chemistry, and biomedical research.
Incorporating fluorine into azoles is not only a common practice but also an essential tactic in medicinal chemistry, due to their ability to fine‐tune a molecule's physicochemical, pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic profiles. The strategic introduction of fluorine into nitrogen‐containing five‐membered heterocycles can significantly enhance metabolic stability, membrane permeability, and binding affinity—key factors in modern drug development. This review provides an up‐to‐date overview of key synthetic strategies for monofluorination, difluoromethylation, and trifluoromethylation across 11 prominent azoles: 1,2,3‐triazoles, 1,2,4‐triazoles, tetrazoles, pyrazoles, imidazoles, pyrroles, isoxazoles, oxazoles, thiazoles, thiadiazoles, and isothiazoles. This review aims to identify current limitations in the field and delineate existing research gaps that present further opportunities for innovation in these domains, which are essential for propelling pharmaceutical and biomedical research. By integrating new synthetic advancements and diverse strategies to access them, this review aims to serve as both a practical guide and a source of inspiration for chemists exploring the next generation of fluorinated azole pharmaceuticals.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Modular Synthesis of Dihydropyranones through Cyclization and Organometallic Functionalization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A scalable method for synthesizing 3‐methoxy‐4,5‐dihydropyran‐2‐ones (MeO‐DHP‐2‐ones) via base‐promoted cyclization of hydroxy alkynes is presented. Mechanistic and computational studies guided the transformation into 4,5‐dihydropyran‐4‐ones (DHP‐4‐ones), enabling access to spiroacetal precursors relevant to natural product synthesis.
Dihydropyranones are key structural motifs in biologically active polyketides. We report a reproducible and scalable method for synthesizing 3‐methoxy‐4,5‐dihydropyran‐2‐ones (MeO‐DHP‐2‐ones) via base‐promoted cyclization of hydroxy alkynes. Mechanistic and computational studies revealed that water content and reaction time critically influence lactonization efficiency. Two optimized protocols – using potassium carbonate (K2CO3) or in situ generated sodium methoxide (MeONa) – enabled consistent yields across multiple substrates. Cyclization in deuterated methanol provided deuterium‐enriched DHP‐2‐one scaffolds with high isotopic incorporation, valuable for mechanistic and medicinal applications. The transformation of DHP‐2‐ones into 4,5‐dihydropyran‐4‐ones (DHP‐4‐ones) was achieved via organometallic addition followed by a tailored workup involving aqueous hydrochloric acid and boron trifluoride diethyl etherate (BF3·OEt2). This protocol proved robust and scalable, compatible with both organolithium and organomagnesium reagents, although the latter afforded lower yields. Mechanistic analysis highlighted key steps including hemiacetal formation, oxonium activation, and controlled hydrolysis. The methodology enables multigram‐scale preparation of both DHP‐2‐one and DHP‐4‐one scaffolds and provides a streamlined route toward spiroacetal precursors.
item.content:encoded:

Mechanistic and computational studies guided the transformation into 4,5-dihydropyran-4-ones (DHP-4-ones), enabling access to spiroacetal precursors relevant to natural product synthesis.


Dihydropyranones are key structural motifs in biologically active polyketides. We report a reproducible and scalable method for synthesizing 3-methoxy-4,5-dihydropyran-2-ones (MeO-DHP-2-ones) via base-promoted cyclization of hydroxy alkynes. Two optimized protocols – using potassium carbonate (K2CO3) or in situ generated sodium methoxide (MeONa) – enabled consistent yields across multiple substrates. Cyclization in deuterated methanol provided deuterium-enriched DHP-2-one scaffolds with high isotopic incorporation, valuable for mechanistic and medicinal applications. The transformation of DHP-2-ones into 4,5-dihydropyran-4-ones (DHP-4-ones) was achieved via organometallic addition followed by a tailored workup involving aqueous hydrochloric acid and boron trifluoride diethyl etherate (BF3·OEt2). This protocol proved robust and scalable, compatible with both organolithium and organomagnesium reagents, although the latter afforded lower yields. Mechanistic analysis highlighted key steps including hemiacetal formation, oxonium activation, and controlled hydrolysis. The methodology enables multigram-scale preparation of both DHP-2-one and DHP-4-one scaffolds and provides a streamlined route toward spiroacetal precursors.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photocatalysis 1,6‐Addition for Site‐Selective Alkylation of para‐Quinone Methides (p‐QMs) via Amidyl Radical 1,2‐Hydrogen Atom Transfer
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A mild photocatalytic protocol synthesizes diverse diarylmethane derivatives (39 examples, good yields) via 1,2‐HAT of N‐benzoyloxyamides generating carbon radicals, followed by selective coupling with para‐quinone methides (p‐QMs).
Under light irradiation, a novel photocatalytic reaction between para‐quinone methides (p‐QMs) and N‐benzoyloxyamides has been developed to synthesize substituted diarylmethane derivatives, which exhibit potential biological activities. This reaction proceeds under mild conditions, affording 39 compounds with good yields and broad substrate applicability. Mechanistic studies reveal that N‐benzoyloxyamides undergo 1,2‐hydrogen atom transfer (1,2‐HAT) to generate carbon‐centered radicals, which subsequently undergo selective radical–radical coupling with p‐QMs to form the diarylmethane framework.
item.content:encoded:
A mild photocatalytic protocol synthesizes diverse diarylmethane derivatives (39 examples, good yields) via 1,2-HAT of N-benzoyloxyamides generating carbon radicals, followed by selective coupling with para-quinone methides (p-QMs).


Under light irradiation, a novel photocatalytic reaction between para-quinone methides (p-QMs) and N-benzoyloxyamides has been developed to synthesize substituted diarylmethane derivatives, which exhibit potential biological activities. This reaction proceeds under mild conditions, affording 39 compounds with good yields and broad substrate applicability. Mechanistic studies reveal that N-benzoyloxyamides undergo 1,2-hydrogen atom transfer (1,2-HAT) to generate carbon-centered radicals, which subsequently undergo selective radical–radical coupling with p-QMs to form the diarylmethane framework.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of (−)‐Mucocin Using a Diastereoselective Oxypalladation and Cross‐Metathesis
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Synthesis of (−)‐mucocin isolated from Rollinia mucosa (Annonaceae) was achieved. Stereoselective construction of the tetrahydropyran (THP) ring moiety was performed using diastereoselective oxypalladation. The tetrahydrofuran (THF) ring moiety was prepared from (S)‐(–)‐malic acid. The cross‐metathesis reaction between the THP and THF moieties afforded the nonadjacent THP–THF core part. Sonogashira cross‐coupling of the γ‐lactone portion with the THP–THF core part followed by reduction of the enyne and removal of the protecting groups afforded (−)‐mucocin.
Synthesis of (−)‐mucocin isolated from Rollinia mucosa (Annonaceae) was achieved. Stereoselective construction of the tetrahydropyran (THP) ring moiety was performed using diastereoselective oxypalladation. The tetrahydrofuran (THF) ring moiety was prepared from (S)‐(−)‐malic acid. The cross‐metathesis reaction between the THP and THF moieties afforded the nonadjacent THP–THF core part. Sonogashira cross‐coupling of the γ‐lactone portion with the THP–THF core part followed by reduction of the enyne and removal of the protecting groups afforded (−)‐mucocin.

Sonogashira cross-coupling of the γ-lactone portion with the THP–THF core part followed by reduction of the enyne and removal of the protecting groups afforded (−)-mucocin.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrochemically Promoted Aminothiocyanation of Unactivated Alkenes for the Synthesis of Thiocyanated Pyrrolidines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Thiocyanated pyrrolidines were synthesized from unactivated alkenes by aminothiocyanation under mild electrochemical conditions. This method features broad substrate scope, excellent selectivity, and enables late‐stage thiocyanation of bioactive molecules.
We report herein an electrochemical aminothiocyanation protocol for the synthesis of thiocyanated pyrrolidines from unactivated alkenes. This method exhibits mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, excellent regioselectivity, and can be applied for late‐stage functionalization of bioactive molecules. Mechanistic studies suggest that the reaction might proceed via a sulfonium ion pathway.
item.content:encoded:

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Reagent‐Controlled Total Synthesis of Natural Anti‐Inflammatory (‐)‐Berkeleyamide A and its Seven Stereoisomers
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Reagent‐driven efficient stereoselective total synthesis of anti‐inflammatory (‐)‐berkeleyamide A, and its unnatural congeners was developed by nonnucleophilic bulky base‐mediated asymmetric aldol reaction from Meldrum's acid.
The total synthesis of anti‐inflammatory (‐)‐berkeleyamide A (with an overall yield of 40%) and its seven stereoisomers was accomplished from inexpensive Meldrum's acid. The reagent‐controlled KOtBu‐mediated syn‐aldol adduct (>76% yield and >90% diastereoselectivity) afforded the natural (10S, 11R,14S)‐(‐)‐berkeleyamide A. Notably, an exclusive anti‐aldol adduct, formed via LiHMDS/TMEDA‐mediated aldol reaction, produced (10S, 11S,14S)‐(‐)‐11‐epi‐berkeleyamide A as a single crystal. While the use of LDA and NaHMDS yielded both syn‐ and antiadducts, enabling access to all stereoisomers. The required aldol partners, chiral γ‐lactam and aliphatic aldehyde, were both produced from Meldrum's acid in 3‐ and 5‐step sequences, respectively, with high yields (each step >87%). The 2D NMR studies and single‐crystal X‐ray crystallographic data assisted in assigning the stereochemistry of all the stereoisomers.
item.content:encoded:
Reagent-driven efficient stereoselective total synthesis of anti-inflammatory (-)-berkeleyamide A, and its unnatural congeners was developed by nonnucleophilic bulky base-mediated asymmetric aldol reaction from Meldrum's acid.


The total synthesis of anti-inflammatory (-)-berkeleyamide A (with an overall yield of 40%) and its seven stereoisomers was accomplished from inexpensive Meldrum's acid. The reagent-controlled KOtBu-mediated syn-aldol adduct (>76% yield and >90% diastereoselectivity) afforded the natural (10S, 11R,14S)-(-)-berkeleyamide A. Notably, an exclusive anti-aldol adduct, formed via LiHMDS/TMEDA-mediated aldol reaction, produced (10S, 11S,14S)-(-)-11-epi-berkeleyamide A as a single crystal. While the use of LDA and NaHMDS yielded both syn- and antiadducts, enabling access to all stereoisomers. The required aldol partners, chiral γ-lactam and aliphatic aldehyde, were both produced from Meldrum's acid in 3- and 5-step sequences, respectively, with high yields (each step >87%). The 2D NMR studies and single-crystal X-ray crystallographic data assisted in assigning the stereochemistry of all the stereoisomers.
item.dc:creator: Anjali Sharma, Smritilekha Bera, Dhananjoy Mondal
item.dc:title: Reagent‐Controlled Total Synthesis of Natural Anti‐Inflammatory (‐)‐Berkeleyamide A and its Seven Stereoisomers

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Experimental and Theoretical Investigations of Copper‐Catalyzed Chemo‐, Regio‐, and Stereoselective cis‐Hydroboration of 1,3‐Enynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A detailed mechanism supported by kinetic experiments, density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and X‐ray crystallography is proposed for the chemo‐, regio‐, and stereoselective hydroboration of 1,3‐enynes. Hydrocupration was determined to be the turnover‐limiting step and essential for selectivity. An off‐cycle, cyclic CuHBpinOAc complex is proposed to explain a positive fractional rate order in catalyst.
The mechanistic details of the chemo‐, regio‐, and stereoselective cis‐hydroboration of 1,3‐enynes were investigated using X‐ray crystallography, kinetic analysis, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The kinetic analysis revealed that the reaction is first order in enyne, zeroth order in HBpin, and fractional order in the catalyst. Our studies suggest that a cyclic CuHBpinOAc complex is an off‐cycle species (via DFT analysis) that contributes to the experimentally observed fractional rate order regarding the catalyst. Experimental and computational data suggest that hydrocupration is rate‐limiting and essential for achieving selectivity.
item.content:encoded:
A detailed mechanism supported by kinetic experiments, density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and X-ray crystallography is proposed for the chemo-, regio-, and stereoselective hydroboration of 1,3-enynes. Hydrocupration was determined to be the turnover-limiting step and essential for selectivity. An off-cycle, cyclic CuHBpinOAc complex is proposed to explain a positive fractional rate order in catalyst.


The mechanistic details of the chemo-, regio-, and stereoselective cis-hydroboration of 1,3-enynes were investigated using X-ray crystallography, kinetic analysis, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The kinetic analysis revealed that the reaction is first order in enyne, zeroth order in HBpin, and fractional order in the catalyst. Our studies suggest that a cyclic CuHBpinOAc complex is an off-cycle species (via DFT analysis) that contributes to the experimentally observed fractional rate order regarding the catalyst. Experimental and computational data suggest that hydrocupration is rate-limiting and essential for achieving selectivity.

item.dc:title: Experimental and Theoretical Investigations of Copper‐Catalyzed Chemo‐, Regio‐, and Stereoselective cis‐Hydroboration of 1,3‐Enynes

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Naphthalene Diimide‐Based Small‐Molecule Semiconductors Enabling Air‐Stable n‐Type Organic Field‐Effect Transistors
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Two novel small molecule semiconductors with low‐lying lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals were designed and synthesized for ambient‐stable organic field‐effect transistors (OFETs) with over 97% electron mobility retained after 2 weeks’ storage in ambient conditions. Flexible OFETs fabricated via air‐water interfacial self‐assembly achieve electron mobility of 4.49 × 10−3 and 7.21 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1.
The development of ambient‐stable n‐type organic semiconductors is a critical yet challenging research frontier. Herein, we report a rational molecular design by functionalizing naphthalene diimide (NDI) cores with strong electron‐withdrawing termini via thiophene bridges. Density functional theory calculations revealed enhanced planarity and significantly lowered lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals energy level (<−4.1 eV), which were corroborated by photophysical and electrochemical analyses. The solution‐processed organic field‐effect transistors (OFETs) demonstrated electron mobilities over 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1, all of which were fabricated and measured under ambient conditions. Remarkably, the devices retained >97% performance after 2‐week storage in ambient conditions. Furthermore, to evaluate the potential of the semiconductors for flexible electronics applications, we fabricated flexible OFETs by integrating the self‐assembled NDI‐4X (X = F, Cl) thin films prepared via air‐water interfacial self‐assembly. Also under ambient conditions, the devices exhibited higher electron mobilities of 4.49 × 10−3 (NDI‐4F) and 7.21 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1(NDI‐4Cl) than their halogen‐free counterpart NDI‐4H (1.14 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1). This work demonstrates that introducing strong electron‐withdrawing groups at both ends of electron‐deficient units provides an effective pathway to achieve ambient‐stable n‐type small‐molecule semiconductors, thereby enabling their application in next‐generation, ambient‐operating flexible organic electronics.
item.content:encoded:
Two novel small molecule semiconductors with low-lying lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals were designed and synthesized for ambient-stable organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) with over 97% electron mobility retained after 2 weeks’ storage in ambient conditions. Flexible OFETs fabricated via air-water interfacial self-assembly achieve electron mobility of 4.49 × 10−3 and 7.21 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1.


The development of ambient-stable n-type organic semiconductors is a critical yet challenging research frontier. Herein, we report a rational molecular design by functionalizing naphthalene diimide (NDI) cores with strong electron-withdrawing termini via thiophene bridges. Density functional theory calculations revealed enhanced planarity and significantly lowered lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals energy level (<−4.1 eV), which were corroborated by photophysical and electrochemical analyses. The solution-processed organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) demonstrated electron mobilities over 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1, all of which were fabricated and measured under ambient conditions. Remarkably, the devices retained >97% performance after 2-week storage in ambient conditions. Furthermore, to evaluate the potential of the semiconductors for flexible electronics applications, we fabricated flexible OFETs by integrating the self-assembled NDI-4X (X = F, Cl) thin films prepared via air-water interfacial self-assembly. Also under ambient conditions, the devices exhibited higher electron mobilities of 4.49 × 10−3 (NDI-4F) and 7.21 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1(NDI-4Cl) than their halogen-free counterpart NDI-4H (1.14 × 10−3 cm2 V−1 s−1). This work demonstrates that introducing strong electron-withdrawing groups at both ends of electron-deficient units provides an effective pathway to achieve ambient-stable n-type small-molecule semiconductors, thereby enabling their application in next-generation, ambient-operating flexible organic electronics.

item.dc:title: Naphthalene Diimide‐Based Small‐Molecule Semiconductors Enabling Air‐Stable n‐Type Organic Field‐Effect Transistors

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis and Physicochemical Characterization of 2‐Azabicyclo[3.2.0]heptane Building Blocks
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An expedient multigram synthesis of diastereopure 2‐azabicyclo[3.2.0]alkane‐derived building blocks is developed by sequential construction of the cyclobutane and pyrrolidine rings by ketene [2+2] cycloaddition and lactam formation, respectively. The title scaffold is characterized by measurements of physicochemical and structural parameters supported by exit vector plot analysis to evaluate its potential for isosteric replacement in medicinal chemistry.
A convenient approach to the synthesis of diastereopure 6‐ and 2,6‐substituted 2‐azabicyclo[3.2.0]hexanes is reported. The method is based on the sequential construction of the cyclobutane and pyrrolidine rings of the target bicyclic system via [2+2] ketene cycloaddition and lactam formation, respectively. Although the key cycloaddition step had modest stereoselectivity (dr 2:1), the target bicyclic product could be obtained as a pure diastereomer without using chromatographic purification. The reaction sequence commences from readily available starting materials and is easily scalable (up to 32.8 g). Utility of the synthesized intermediates is demonstrated by the preparation of a series of exo‐ and endo‐isomeric amino alcohols and monoprotected diamines—valuable building blocks for drug discovery. Their potential for isosteric replacements is evaluated by measuring physicochemical properties, as well as structural studies and exit vector plot analysis.

The title scaffold is characterized by measurements of physicochemical and structural parameters supported by exit vector plot analysis to evaluate its potential for isosteric replacement in medicinal chemistry.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: From Light‐Driven to Dark Synthesis: Streamlining Perfluoroalkyl Selenide Ether Formation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Two orthogonal and user‐friendly protocols enable the efficient construction of (Se/S)RF bonds from simple dichalcogenides and perfluoroalkyl iodides. Visible‐light irradiation at 395 nm promotes seleno‐ and thioether formation, while a dark KOH/MeCN variant delivers selenoethers in minutes. Both approaches operate under mild, metal‐ and photocatalyst‐free conditions, tolerate biologically relevant substrates, and scale smoothly to gram quantities.
Two complementary and operationally simple methods enable the efficient perfluoroalkylation of organodiselenides: (i) direct visible‐light irradiation at 395 nm in aqueous MeCN with RF–I, requiring no photocatalyst, and (ii) a base‐promoted protocol using KOH in MeCN under dark conditions. Both furnished perfluoroalkyl selenoethers in excellent yields, while only the photoinduced protocol delivered good to excellent yields of perfluoroalkyl thioethers from organodisulfides. The direct irradiation approach also enables the preparation of Se‐ and S‐perfluoroalkylated derivatives of selenocysteine and cysteine, highlighting the applicability to biologically relevant substrates. Both protocols feature excellent chemical selectivity, good functional group tolerance, mild conditions, and simple operation. Compared with existing photocatalytic and thermal methods, these approaches provide greater versatility and operational simplicity, exemplified by the gram‐scale synthesis of a perfluoroalkyl selenoether in excellent yield.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in Iron‐Photocatalyzed Decarboxylative CC Bond Formation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review summarizes recent progress in photoinduced iron‐catalyzed decarboxylative CC bond formation using alkyl carboxylic acids and their derivatives as radical precursors. It emphasizes the mechanistic insights, substrate versatility, and synthetic utility of this environmentally benign strategy, highlighting its potential for constructing complex molecules and its growing impact in modern organic synthesis.
In recent years, iron‐photocatalyzed decarboxylative CC bond formation has emerged as a sustainable and versatile strategy in synthetic chemistry. This approach harnesses earth‐abundant and cost‐effective iron complexes, which undergo ligand‐to‐metal charge transfer under visible‐light irradiation to generate alkyl radicals directly from readily available carboxylic acids. The resulting radical intermediates participate in diverse CC bond‐forming processes, including alkyl−alkyl, alkyl−aryl, and alkyl−alkenyl couplings, enabling rapid access to structurally complex scaffolds from simple feedstock chemicals. In this perspective review, recent progress in substrate scope, catalytic design, and mechanistic understanding, is highlighted with particular emphasis on synthetic applications in late‐stage functionalization and pharmaceutical intermediate construction. These advances not only underscore the unique reactivity of iron photocatalysts but also point toward future opportunities for expanding their utility in green and scalable CC bond‐forming methodologies.
item.content:encoded:

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Pot Synthesis of Ferrocene Thioamides from Ferrocenecarboxaldehyde via the Willgerodt–Kindler Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A series of ferrocene thioamides is synthesized via Willgerodt–Kindler reaction from ferrocenecarboxaldehyde. Two experimental protocols are developed to effectively employ both primary and secondary amines. The solvent screening reveals a highly positive effect of amide solvent on the reaction. Mechanistic study helps to elucidate the role of Na2S as promoted rather than the catalyst.
Ferrocene thioamides are potential alternatives for classical oxoamide‐type ferrocene ligands with broad applications in metal‐catalyzed transformations as well as substrates for CH activations and applications in other fields. A reaction of ferrocenecarboxaldehyde with various amines and sulfur promoted by sodium sulfide furnishes a wide range of ferrocene thioamides via the Willgerodt–Kindler multicomponent reaction. The detailed solvent screening reveals that amide‐type solvents are highly beneficial for the reaction. The steric hindrance of bulky amine substrates limits the reaction. While secondary amines require only conventional heating, primary amines yield better results with microwave irradiation at higher temperatures. The mechanism is investigated using nuclear magnetic resonance kinetic measurements, which show that Na2S acts as a promoter, rather than a catalyst, of the reaction.
item.content:encoded:

Mechanistic study helps to elucidate the role of Na2S as promoted rather than the catalyst.


Ferrocene thioamides are potential alternatives for classical oxoamide-type ferrocene ligands with broad applications in metal-catalyzed transformations as well as substrates for CH activations and applications in other fields. A reaction of ferrocenecarboxaldehyde with various amines and sulfur promoted by sodium sulfide furnishes a wide range of ferrocene thioamides via the Willgerodt–Kindler multicomponent reaction. The detailed solvent screening reveals that amide-type solvents are highly beneficial for the reaction. The steric hindrance of bulky amine substrates limits the reaction. While secondary amines require only conventional heating, primary amines yield better results with microwave irradiation at higher temperatures. The mechanism is investigated using nuclear magnetic resonance kinetic measurements, which show that Na2S acts as a promoter, rather than a catalyst, of the reaction.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Vicinal Pyrazolyl‐Phosphine Imines and their Palladium Complexes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Pyrazolyl phosphines bearing a vicinal aminal group are synthesized and hydrolyzed to formyl derivatives and cyclic phosphonium salts, with product ratios depending on HCl concentration. The corresponding methylimines act as bidentate ligands forming Pd(II) complexes, while phosphonium salts afford a Pd(IV) complex confirmed by X‐ray crystallography.
Readily available 4‐bromo‐5‐(N,N,N′‐trimethyl‐N‐(trimethylsilyl)diamino‐methyl)pyrazoles are employed as starting materials for the synthesis of pyrazolyl phosphines. Subsequent hydrolysis yields the expected 4‐diphenylphosphino‐5‐formylpyrazoles, accompanied by the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. The product distribution is found to depend on the concentration of hydrochloric acid: higher acid concentrations favored the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. A similar behavior is observed for the methylimines derived from 4‐diphenylphosphino‐5‐formylpyrazoles. These imines acted as bidentate ligands, readily forming palladium(II) complexes. In contrast, the cyclic phosphonium salts reacted with dichlorobis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) to afford a palladium(IV) complex, the structure of which is confirmed by X‐ray crystallography.

Readily available 4-bromo-5-(N,N,N′-trimethyl-N-(trimethylsilyl)diamino-methyl)pyrazoles are employed as starting materials for the synthesis of pyrazolyl phosphines. Subsequent hydrolysis yields the expected 4-diphenylphosphino-5-formylpyrazoles, accompanied by the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. A similar behavior is observed for the methylimines derived from 4-diphenylphosphino-5-formylpyrazoles. These imines acted as bidentate ligands, readily forming palladium(II) complexes. In contrast, the cyclic phosphonium salts reacted with dichlorobis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) to afford a palladium(IV) complex, the structure of which is confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxygen‐Directed Sulfinylation of Distal C(sp3)H Bonds by Photoredox Catalysis
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A photoredox/copper‐cocatalyzed remote CH sulfoxidation reaction is described that proceeds through radical‐mediated 1,5−hydrogen atom transfer. A visible‐light‐driven copper‐catalyzed cross‐coupling reaction between N−alkoxypyridinium salts and sodium arylsulfinates gave a series of hydroxy sulfoxide derivatives. This transformation features redox‐neutral conditions, broad functional group compatibility, and excellent site selectivity.
An efficient photoredox‐catalyzed reaction is reported for site‐selective C(sp3)H sulfoxidation of N‐alkoxypyridinium salts using sodium arylsulfinates as sulfinyl donors. This transformation involves alkoxy‐radical‐directed 1,5‐hydrogen atom transfer (1,5−HAT) followed by C(sp3)S bond formation. A visible‐light‐driven, copper‐catalyzed cross‐coupling strategy enables the synthesis of a series of hydroxyl sulfoxide derivatives. This methodology establishes a novel synthetic platform for rapid construction of sulfoxide‐containing molecular architectures, demonstrating remarkable functional group compatibility and predictable regioselectivity.
item.content:encoded:

A visible-light-driven copper-catalyzed cross-coupling reaction between N−alkoxypyridinium salts and sodium arylsulfinates gave a series of hydroxy sulfoxide derivatives. This transformation features redox-neutral conditions, broad functional group compatibility, and excellent site selectivity.


An efficient photoredox-catalyzed reaction is reported for site-selective C(sp3)H sulfoxidation of N-alkoxypyridinium salts using sodium arylsulfinates as sulfinyl donors. This transformation involves alkoxy-radical-directed 1,5-hydrogen atom transfer (1,5−HAT) followed by C(sp3)S bond formation. A visible-light-driven, copper-catalyzed cross-coupling strategy enables the synthesis of a series of hydroxyl sulfoxide derivatives. This methodology establishes a novel synthetic platform for rapid construction of sulfoxide-containing molecular architectures, demonstrating remarkable functional group compatibility and predictable regioselectivity.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrochemical Tandem Self‐Coupling/Selenylation of Acetonitrile toward Highly Functionalized Tetrasubstituted Alkenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Electrochemical tandem self‐coupling/selenylation of acetonitrile delivers (Z)‐tetrasubstituted alkenes with amino, cyano, and seleno groups. This potassium iodide‐mediated, metal/oxidant‐free protocol features simple operation, high chemoselectivity, and excellent stereoselectivity.
Herein, an electrochemical tandem reaction that integrates acetonitrile self‐coupling with selenylation to construct densely functionalized tetrasubstituted alkenes bearing amino, cyano, and seleno groups from readily available acetonitrile and diselenides is reported. Employing potassium iodide as a redox mediator under mild, metal‐free, and oxidant‐free conditions, this sustainable strategy leverages the synergistic effect of electrochemical oxidation and iodine catalysis to achieve inert C(sp3)H bond activation of acetonitrile. The transformation exhibits good stereoselectivity along with substrate scope across diverse aryl and alkyl selenides.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Green Multicomponent One‐Pot Synthesis of 2‐(2′‐Hydroxyphenyl)Imidazo[1,2‐a]Pyridine Analogs with an Intramolecular Hydrogen‐Bonded Eight‐Membered Ring Exhibiting Excited‐State Intramolecular Proton Transfer Luminescence
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Sonochemical multicomponent synthesis of 2‐(2´‐hydroxyphenyl)imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridine analogs with an intramolecular hydrogen‐bonded eight‐membered ring exhibiting an excited‐state intramolecular proton transfer fluorescent process.
Multicomponent reactions are excellent tools to generate complex structures with broad chemical diversity and fluorescent properties. The sonochemical multicomponent one‐pot synthesis of novel organic luminescent heterocycles, such as 2‐(2′‐hydroxyphenyl)imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridine (2‐HPIP) analogs, is described. The Groebke–Blackburn–Bienaymé reaction (GBBR) affords good to excellent yields (75–95%). Notably, the compound 4b forms an intramolecular hydrogen‐bonded eight‐membered ring (8‐MR) in the crystalline state and is luminescent in this phase; in solution, this compound exhibits dual band emission with a very large Stokes shift of 18 382 cm−1 attributed to an excited‐state intramolecular proton transfer (ESIPT) process. Time‐dependent density functional theory (TD‐DFT) and additional calculations are performed to evaluate the HOMO–LUMO distributions and theoretical absorption spectra, being in agreement with the experimental data. Additionally, the TD‐DFT calculations in solution (chloroform) show the ESIPT process and 8‐MR formation become thermodynamically favorable in 4b. This work represents the first synthesis of prompts feasibility ESIPT heterocyclic luminescent materials via an eight‐membered ring (8‐MR) with an N···HO connection.
item.content:encoded:
Sonochemical multicomponent synthesis of 2-(2´-hydroxyphenyl)imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine  analogs with an intramolecular hydrogen-bonded eight-membered ring exhibiting an excited-state intramolecular proton transfer fluorescent process.


Multicomponent reactions are excellent tools to generate complex structures with broad chemical diversity and fluorescent properties. The sonochemical multicomponent one-pot synthesis of novel organic luminescent heterocycles, such as 2-(2′-hydroxyphenyl)imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine (2-HPIP) analogs, is described. The Groebke–Blackburn–Bienaymé reaction (GBBR) affords good to excellent yields (75–95%). Notably, the compound 4b forms an intramolecular hydrogen-bonded eight-membered ring (8-MR) in the crystalline state and is luminescent in this phase; in solution, this compound exhibits dual band emission with a very large Stokes shift of 18 382 cm−1 attributed to an excited-state intramolecular proton transfer (ESIPT) process. Time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) and additional calculations are performed to evaluate the HOMO–LUMO distributions and theoretical absorption spectra, being in agreement with the experimental data. Additionally, the TD-DFT calculations in solution (chloroform) show the ESIPT process and 8-MR formation become thermodynamically favorable in 4b. This work represents the first synthesis of prompts feasibility ESIPT heterocyclic luminescent materials via an eight-membered ring (8-MR) with an N···HO connection.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrochemical Tandem Cyclization of N‐(But‐3‐en‐1‐yl)Anilines to Access Trifluoromethylated Tetrahydroquinoline Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
In this study, a series of 34 trifluoromethylated tetrahydroquinoline derivatives were synthesized through a one‐step trifluoromethylation/cyclization cascade reaction, enabling the simultaneous construction of two CC bonds. This transformation was achieved using a green and efficient electrocatalytic approach, without requiring metal catalysts. Control experiments suggest that the reaction likely proceeds via a radical‐initiated mechanism.
A novel electrochemical cascade strategy enables dual CC bond formation through trifluoromethylation and C(sp2)‐H functionalization of N‐(but‐3‐en‐1‐yl)anilines derivatives. This protocol efficiently constructs structurally diverse trifluoromethylated tetrahydroquinoline derivatives in moderate to good yields. It operates under mild reaction conditions, uses readily available substrates, proceeds without metal catalysts, and achieves the construction of two CC bonds in a single step. Detailed mechanistic studies demonstrate that a sequential single‐electron transfer (SET) process triggers the radical cascade reaction.

Control experiments suggest that the reaction likely proceeds via a radical-initiated mechanism.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Regiocontrolled Cleavage of Dialkyl Ethers Using Regenerative Borates as a Sustainable Alternative to Boron Trichloride
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The use of triaryl borates for highly selective ether cleavage is described. The borate is regenerable from the aqueous extract of a previous ether cleavage reaction without repurification, making use of low toxicity boron and phenolic waste. Such strategies for CO cleavage are expected to be broadly applicable to synthetic manipulations where management of waste is critical.
Ethers are ubiquitous functional groups in natural products, surfactants, and materials, making them valuable targets for chemical diversification. This report advances a previously reported method utilizing a 1:1 mixture of BBr3 and BCl3 to cleave unsymmetric dialkyl ethers with high regio‐ and chemoselectivity. In this new protocol, regenerable triaryl borates are used in place of BCl3, offering a more sustainable approach. Importantly, all boron‐containing byproducts from the reaction can be converted back into the triaryl borate, enabling full reagent recovery. The speciation of borate/BBr3 mixtures is monitored by 11B‐NMR and compared to the previously studied BCl3/BBr3 system. Additionally, Design of Experiments (DOE) statistical analysis reveals a correlation between borate Lewis acidity and cleavage selectivity. The triaryl borate regenerated in situ from aqueous waste performs comparably to freshly prepared material in subsequent reactions. Overall, this system matches or exceeds the performance of the original BBr3/BCl3 method across a broad range of dialkyl ether substrates.

Such strategies for CO cleavage are expected to be broadly applicable to synthetic manipulations where management of waste is critical.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: All‐Visible‐Light Diarylethene Photoswitches and Control over Dynamic Conjugate Addition Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This work introduces visible‐light‐driven photoswitches by fusing α,β‐unsaturated 1,3‐dicarbonyl motif with dithienylethene (DTE) scaffold. The photoswitches exhibit reversible photochromic behavior under visible‐light, with enhanced efficiency through electronic modulation. Moreover, DTEs enable visible‐light‐controlled CS bond formation and cleavage, providing a platform for recyclable and biocompatible materials.
All‐visible‐light‐driven photoswitches are gaining significant attention for their environmental friendliness and biocompatibility. Here, a series of visible‐light responsive photoswitches is presented by embedding α,β‐unsaturated 1,3‐dicarbonyl motifs into the ethene bridge of dithienylethene (DTE) scaffolds. Through electronic modulation and π‐conjugation extension, the absorption is redshifted into the visible range, enabling reversible photochromic ring‐closure and ring‐opening under blue and red light, respectively. Density functional theory calculations reveal that electron‐withdrawing groups and extended conjugation narrow the HOMO–LUMO gap, enhancing photoswitching efficiency. Furthermore, these photoswitches also function as dynamic Michael acceptors, allowing visible‐light‐controlled CS bond formation and cleavage with great reversibility. The work described offers a versatile platform for visible‐light‐regulated dynamic covalent chemistry and paves the way for the development of recyclable, biocompatible materials.

Moreover, DTEs enable visible-light-controlled CS bond formation and cleavage, providing a platform for recyclable and biocompatible materials.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Organolanthanum‐Mediated Coupling of 2‐Bromobiaryls with Ester Electrophiles to Access Valuable Biaryl Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Dibenzofulvenes (DBFs) and 9,10‐phenanthrenequinones (PQs) are synthesized through a coupling reaction of 2‐bromobiaryl compounds with different ester electrophiles by using the unique reactivity of organolanthanum heterocyclic intermediates. This method features a one‐pot procedure, transition‐metal‐free conditions, readily available substrates, and the ability to provide direct access to both DBFs and PQs.
Dibenzofulvenes (DBFs) and 9,10‐phenanthrenequinones (PQs) are valuable biaryl derivatives with unique applications in many fields. The development of their synthetic methods is of great importance in organic synthesis. A one‐pot coupling reaction of 2‐bromobiaryls with ester electrophiles is reported, exploiting the exceptional reactivity of organolanthanum heterocyclic intermediates. The reaction enables precise installation of CC and CO moieties at the 2,2′‐positions of biaryl scaffolds, providing convenient access to DBFs and PQs with high efficiency and good substrate availability.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxidative Functionalization of Amines Using an Electrocatalytic Aminoxyl‐Mediated Reaction: Preparation of N‐Benzylidenebenzylamines from Benzylamines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A methodology for the preparation of imines from amines by means of an electrocatalytic aminoxyl‐mediated reaction.
A methodology is reported for the preparation of imines from amines by means of an electrocatalytic aminoxyl‐mediated reaction. It is performed using readily available electrodes in a commercially available electrochemistry apparatus and does not require the use of a reference electrode. The methodology proceeds under mild conditions and delivers good to excellent isolated yields across a range of structurally diverse benzyl amines. Selectivity is high, with imines obtained in preference to the more commonly reported nitriles, and the process is readily scalable to the gram level. Operational simplicity and short reaction times make this method a valuable addition to the organic chemist's toolkit.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A New Methodology for Preparing Benzylated Aminopyridines Yields Previously Inaccessible Organocatalysts
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
ZnBr2‐induced benzylation of 4‐aminopyridineswith suitable alcohols or diols provides access to novel organocatalysts of the unprecedented diarylpyrrolidionopyridine type, as well as new benzylmethylaminopyridine catalysts. These catalysts are practically inaccessible by other routes and exhibit high activity and site selectivity in the phosphorylation of amphiphilic diols.
p‐Dialkylaminopyridines represent a key class of nucleophilic organocatalysts, widely used in alcohol‐modifying reactions, among other applications. However, access to certain variants of these catalysts, particularly those with sterically congested secondary sphere, remains challenging or even unfeasible using previously established synthetic routes. Lewis acid‐promoted benzylation or cyclative dibenzylation of simple aminopyridines with corresponding alcohols effectively overcomes these shortcomings. This innovative approach enables the synthesis of previously inaccessible (2,5‐diarylpyrrolidino)pyridines and novel (N‐benzyl‐N‐methylamino)pyridines bearing extended ortho‐alkoxy tails on the aryl substituents. The new catalysts, characterized by their bulky secondary sphere, exhibit outstanding activity and high site‐selectivity in the phosphorylation of a model diol amphiphile.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Exploration of Structure–Property Relationships by Altering Glycol Backbone Unsaturation (Double/Triple Bonds) in Furan‐Based Polyesters
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This study explores how adding unsaturated groups to bio‐based furanic polyesters can change their stiffness and heat resistance. While this offers new possibilities, it also needs careful control during production. It is shown that solution polycondensation works well for making these materials and offers a path toward more flexible, stable, and ecofriendly polymers.
This study highlights both the challenges and opportunities associated with developing bio‐based furanic polyesters. Incorporating unsaturated moieties into glycol chains effectively modulates polymer rigidity and thermal properties, though it requires careful optimization of polymerization conditions. The findings demonstrate the viability of solution polycondensation for synthesizing high‐quality FDCA‐based polyesters with unsaturated glycols and pave the way for further investigations into polymer design strategies that balance flexibility, thermal stability, and environmental sustainability.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Basicity and Lipophilicity of gem‐Difluorinated Saturated Bicyclic Amines: Advanced Building Blocks for Drug Discovery
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A detailed study of the physicochemical properties of gem‐difluorinated bicyclic amines is reported. pKa and LogP measurements reveal interesting trends affected by the fluorination pattern of the compound and the bicyclic system itself, which are partially rationalized through molecular electrostatic potential surface analysis.
The impact of gem‐difluorination on the physicochemical properties of bicyclic saturated amines with 6–8 atoms in the largest ring is studied. The fluorination effect on the acidity of protonated species (pKa) aligns with predictions based on the inductive effect of the electron‐deficient substituent. In contrast, lipophilicity (LogP) could either increase or decrease due to gem‐difluorination. The observed effect depends on the number of vicinal CH bonds relative to the fluorine atoms, but it is also influenced by their relative spatial orientation and the structure of the bicyclic core itself.
item.content:encoded:
A detailed study of the physicochemical properties of gem-difluorinated bicyclic amines is reported. pK a and LogP measurements reveal interesting trends affected by the fluorination pattern of the compound and the bicyclic system itself, which are partially rationalized through molecular electrostatic potential surface analysis.


The impact of gem-difluorination on the physicochemical properties of bicyclic saturated amines with 6–8 atoms in the largest ring is studied. The fluorination effect on the acidity of protonated species (pK a) aligns with predictions based on the inductive effect of the electron-deficient substituent. In contrast, lipophilicity (LogP) could either increase or decrease due to gem-difluorination. The observed effect depends on the number of vicinal CH bonds relative to the fluorine atoms, but it is also influenced by their relative spatial orientation and the structure of the bicyclic core itself.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Exploring the Chemical Reactivity of Triisopropylsilyl Dialkynylmethanol for the Synthesis of Dialkynylcarbinol‐Related Compounds
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The relevance of 1‐(triisopropylsilyl)penta‐1,4‐diyn‐3‐ol as a versatile C5 organic framework is highlighted in both racemic and enantiopure form thanks to a finely optimized lipase‐mediated enzymatic kinetic resolution procedure. This straightforward approach, exploiting the reactivity of the terminal alkyne group, opened the way for the most cytotoxic series to date of bioinspired lipidic alkynylcarbinols.
Prompted by the pharmacological relevance of lipidic alkynylcarbinols, 1‐(triisopropylsilyl)penta‐1,4‐diyn‐3‐ol is exploited as a versatile C5 organic framework. Selective functionalization of this dissymmetrical dialkynylcarbinol precursor is achieved via the creation of either a Csp–Csp (alkyne), a Csp–Csp2 (alkene and aryl), or a Csp–Csp3 (RCHOH) bond. A novel series of racemic HSD17B11‐bioactivated procytotoxic acetylenic lipids is accessed that revealed, amongst the most potent to date, with IC50 down to 27 nM on osteosarcoma U2OS cells. Click‐type 1,3‐dipolar cycloadditions, such as a copper‐catalyzed reaction with a long‐chain alkyl azide (CuAAC) and a base‐promoted reaction with a lipidic nitrile oxide, are first described in a racemic version. Preparation of both enantiomers of 1‐(triisopropylsilyl)penta‐1,4‐diyn‐3‐ol through kinetic enzymatic resolution with CAL‐B immobilized on acrylic resin is carefully optimized. Finally, the use of resolved samples in 1,3‐dipolar cycloaddition reactions leads to the enantioenriched cycloadducts without significant epimerization of the carbinol center.
item.content:encoded:

This straightforward approach, exploiting the reactivity of the terminal alkyne group, opened the way for the most cytotoxic series to date of bioinspired lipidic alkynylcarbinols.


Prompted by the pharmacological relevance of lipidic alkynylcarbinols, 1-(triisopropylsilyl)penta-1,4-diyn-3-ol is exploited as a versatile C5 organic framework. A novel series of racemic HSD17B11-bioactivated procytotoxic acetylenic lipids is accessed that revealed, amongst the most potent to date, with IC50 down to 27 nM on osteosarcoma U2OS cells. item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Amidine Syntheses from Classic to Contemporary for Medicinal Lead Compounds and Natural Products
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A revolution is underway in the synthesis of amidines with new methods unlocking complex, highly substituted amidines or closely related derivatives such as N‐sulfonyl amidines. This review surveys recent advances in amidines and related compounds, including methods to install them and bioactive molecules prominently featuring the amidine functionality.
For close to 150 years, the Pinner reaction between nitriles and amines dominated the syntheses of amidines. Today, the Pinner reaction remains highly over‐represented in recent syntheses of unsubstituted or simple amidines. However, a number of greener amidine syntheses unlock access to more complex, highly substituted amidines, or closely related derivatives such as N‐sulfonyl amidines. This review surveys recent advances in amidines and related compounds, including methods to install them and bioactive molecules prominently featuring the amidine functionality. Complex amidines are readily synthesized using both traditional and multicomponent reactions, which often involve metals. Recent trends include metal‐free methodologies and expanded structural diversity of amidine products. The second half of this article reviews the utility of amidines as carbonyl bioisosteres for natural products, functional linkers, or as a bioactive functional group. The biological activities of recently reported amidine‐based compounds will be surveyed with an emphasis on promising antibacterial and antiproliferative compounds.

This review surveys recent advances in amidines and related compounds, including methods to install them and bioactive molecules prominently featuring the amidine functionality.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multistep Reactions Initiated by Amine‐Based Organometallic Methods
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 40, October 29, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The advent of C–H activation and other organometallic methodologies making use of transient directing groups or free amines themselves for the elaboration of amine substrates provides unique access to cascade‐type reactions that can generate significant molecular complexity in one pot.
The pursuit of atom‐ and step‐economical pathways to access complex heterocycles and functionalized scaffolds has driven advances in the use of transient and free amine directing groups that exploit native coordination properties for multistep synthesis. Traditional protection‐functionalization‐deprotection sequences, while effective in some circumstances, introduce inefficiencies that compound across multistep syntheses. The following strategies address three critical challenges: 1) eliminating auxiliary installation/removal, 2) enabling multistep functionalization without intermediate isolation (in many cases), and 3) maintaining compatibility with sensitive functional groups. This review aims to collectively summarize the developments in amine‐based synthesis that make use of the amine both as a directing group and a reactive partner in subsequent reaction steps. By analyzing mechanistic insights and substrate scope limitations across these methodologies, one can identify unresolved challenges and provide insight on future directions.

This review aims to collectively summarize the developments in amine-based synthesis that make use of the amine both as a directing group and a reactive partner in subsequent reaction steps. item.title: Electrochemical α‐Hydroxymethylation of Aryl Ketones with Methanol
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
β‐hydroxy ketones represent a class of compounds with broad applications in pharmaceuticals and bioactive molecules. However, the synthesis of these compounds often encounters various challenges. Herein, an electrochemical method is reported that utilizes methanol as a C1 source, enabling the α‐hydroxymethylation of a series of aryl ketones under oxidant‐free conditions. This approach achieves high yields and exhibits broad substrate compatibility.
β‐hydroxy ketones represent a class of compounds with broad applications in pharmaceuticals and bioactive molecules. However, the synthesis of these compounds often encounters various challenges. Herein, an electrochemical method is reported that utilizes methanol as a C1 source, enabling the α‐hydroxymethylation of a series of aryl ketones under oxidant‐free conditions for constructing β‐hydroxy ketones. This approach achieves high yields and exhibits broad substrate compatibility. Mechanistic investigations indicate that the reaction proceeds via a radical pathway, rather than through conventional methanol oxidation to formaldehyde.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Toward Novel Trifluoromethylated Peptidomimetics: A Case Study of Cathepsin C Inhibitors
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A series of CF3‐containing amino acid analogues is prepared and studied by docking to Cathepsin C. The results highlight their potential as peptidomimetics and showcase the value of fluorination in drug design.
Herein, both synthetic and theoretical results related to the development of amino acid analogues containing a CF3‐olefinic moiety and their evaluation as potential inhibitors of Cathepsin C are presented. The key synthetic steps include the trifluoromethylation using the Ruppert–Prakash reagent and a Horner–Wadsworth–Emmons olefination to obtain the desired CF3‐alkenyl amino acid derivatives. In recent years, theoretical approaches based on molecular docking have gained significant attention for predicting the biological activity of synthetic compounds as enzyme inhibitors. The research specifically targets Cathepsin C, also known as dipeptidyl peptidase I, a protease that plays a crucial role in activating various degradative enzymes involved in tissue damage during inflammatory diseases.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Convenient Synthesis of C‐Linked β‐D‐Galactosides with Lipophilic Aglycone Component Toward Lectin A Inhibition and Antibiofilm Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an ESKAPE pathogen, relies on lectin A (LecA) for adhesion, biofilm formation, and virulence making it a promising therapeutic target. Hydrolytically stable novel C‐linked monovalent D‐galactosides A, B, and C with lipophilic aglycone component are synthesized using Weinreb‐amide‐based building block 15 and are evaluated for bacterial biofilm inhibition activity.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a member of the World Health Organization‐listed ESKAPE pathogens, exhibits high drug resistance and relies on the galactose‐specific lectin LecA for adhesion, biofilm formation, and virulence. Targeting lectin A (LecA) emerges as a promising antivirulence strategy. While multivalent D‐galactoside derivatives demonstrate strong LecA binding and biofilm disruption, their high molecular weight, synthetic complexity, and poor pharmacokinetic profiles limit clinical potential. In contrast, monovalent β‐D‐galactosides with aromatic aglycons offer improved drug‐likeness and bioavailability, though typically with moderate potency. The hydrophobic pocket adjacent to LecA's binding site inspires lipophilic modifications to enhance activity, yet most inhibitors remain O‐ or S‐linked glycosides. C‐linked β‐D‐galactosides, which are hydrolytically more stable, remain underexplored. Motivated by their potential advantages, the design and synthesis of hitherto unreported monovalent C‐linked β‐D‐galactoside ligands with aryl aglycones, represented by general structures A, B, and C, is proposed as new LecA inhibitors for combating P. aeruginosa biofilm.
item.content:encoded:

Hydrolytically stable novel C-linked monovalent D-galactosides A, B, and C with lipophilic aglycone component are synthesized using Weinreb-amide-based building block 15 and are evaluated for bacterial biofilm inhibition activity.

Motivated by their potential advantages, the design and synthesis of hitherto unreported monovalent C-linked β-D-galactoside ligands with aryl aglycones, represented by general structures A, B, and C, is proposed as new LecA inhibitors for combating P. aeruginosa biofilm.

item.dc:title: Convenient Synthesis of C‐Linked β‐D‐Galactosides with Lipophilic Aglycone Component Toward Lectin A Inhibition and Antibiofilm Properties

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrocatalytic CH Annulation of Alkynes to Functionalized Heterocycles: Synthesis and Mechanical Insights
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Electrochemical CH annulation of alkynes represents a sustainable and efficient pathway for constructing functionalized heterocycles. This work highlights, how alkyne integration enables the creation of nitrogen‐ and oxygen‐containing scaffolds with adaptable features for pharmaceuticals, materials, and catalysis. Integrating transition‐metal and metal‐free electrocatalysis, this overviews the selective and eco‐friendly routes for redefining heterocycle synthesis through controlled alkyne activation.
Heterocyclic frameworks are indispensable in pharmaceuticals, advanced materials, and catalysis owing to their diverse structures and wide‐ranging functionalities. In recent years, electrochemical CH annulation using alkynes has emerged as a green and selective platform for the efficient construction of these complex systems. By avoiding stoichiometric oxidants and enabling reagent‐free processes, this methodology reduces environmental impact while improving synthetic efficiency. Alkyne incorporation plays a pivotal role in modulating the electronic and biological properties of nitrogen‐ and oxygen‐rich heterocycles, which are prominent in bioactive compounds. Innovations in electro‐oxidative processes and transition‐metal catalysis have significantly advanced the field, allowing for precise and sustainable transformations. Herein, the synthesis of functionalized heterocycles employing annulation of alkynes electrocatalytically, role of catalysts, and mechanistic insights are overviewed by critically investigating the recent progress in crafting next‐generation heterocyclic scaffolds with functional versatility.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Hypervalent‐Iodine‐Mediated Synthesis of Sulfinamides from Sulfenamides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An efficient approach to sulfinamides from sulfenamides is developed by using PhI(OAc)2/H2O, which features mild and metal‐free conditions, high to excellent yields, and good functional group compatibility. In particular, the products obtained can be readily converted into many potentially bioactive sulfur‐containing compounds.
A concise approach to access sulfinamides from sulfenamides is developed by using PhI(OAc)2/H2O. This protocol features mild and metal‐free conditions, high to excellent yields, and good functional group compatibility and provides an efficient and green route to sulfinamide derivatives. Importantly, the products obtained can be readily converted into potentially bioactive sulfonamides, sulfilimines, sulfonimidoyl halides, and sulfinimidate compounds for medicinal research, thus exhibiting diversified synthetic potential.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iodine‐Catalyzed C3–H Sulfinylation of Indoles with Sulfenamides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This study proposes an efficient iodine‐catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation of indoles, employing sulfenamides as sustainable sulfur sources under transition‐metal‐ and oxidant‐free conditions.
Organic sulfides, particularly 3‐sulfinylindoles, have garnered substantial attention owing to their remarkable pharmacological activities and broad applications in materials science and pesticide chemistry. Nevertheless, traditional synthetic approaches for 3‐sulfinylindoles usually suffer from drawbacks such as toxic reagents, dependence on transition‐metal catalysts, and severe reaction conditions. Herein, an iodine‐catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation strategy is presented for the synthesis of 3‐sulfinylindoles, employing sulfenamides as stable and odorless sulfenylating reagents. This protocol proceeds under mild conditions (100 °C in 1,2‐dichloroethane) without extra oxidants or additives, delivering a broad range of 3‐sulfinylindole derivatives in moderate to excellent yields. Substrate scope investigations demonstrate excellent compatibility with indoles having electron‐donating/withdrawing groups and sulfenamides containing aromatic/heterocyclic groups. This method addresses critical challenges in traditional sulfinylation, providing a green, metal‐free, and efficient approach for the construction of thiofunctionalized indole derivatives with potential applications in drug discovery and functional materials.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthetic Access to the Class of 3‐Amino‐4‐Cyano‐Substituted Thiophenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of 1,1‐dibromo‐3,4,4‐trichloro‐2‐cyano‐1,3‐butadiene opens a first pathway to 3‐amino‐4‐cyano‐thiophenes. These compounds display a push–pull substitution pattern that allows for selective modifications at the 2 and 5 positions. Through S‐oxidation, substitution, and reduction valuable halo and hydrothiophenes are generated, which could be serve as important monomers for the development of highly conductive polythiophenes, while maintaining their essential 3‐push‐4‐pull structural characteristic.
The synthesis of 1,1‐dibromo‐3,4,4‐trichloro‐2‐cyano‐1,3‐butadiene (3) provides a selective access to the new class of 3‐amino‐4‐cyano‐thiophenes 2. The unique push–pull substitution pattern of 2 allows a chemoselective modification in the 2 and 5 positions. Derivatization of 2 is accomplished by selective S‐oxidation of the vinylsulfanyl unit. Substitution of the resulting vinylsulfinyl group of 14 by halogen nucleophiles led to dihalothiophenes 16 and 17 in good yields. A subsequent selective dehalogenation in the 2 and 5 positions is accomplished, leaving the 3,4‐push–pull unit untouched. The new 2,5‐dihalothiophenes, as well as the 2,5‐unsubstituted thiophene 20, are interesting monomers for the preparation of highly conducting polythiophenes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multicomponent Strategy for the Synthesis of 2,3‐Dihydro‐4H‐Imidazol‐4‐Ones under Catalyst‐ and Additive‐Free Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A catalyst‐ and additive‐free multicomponent reaction is developed to synthesize 2,3‐dihydro‐4H‐imidazol‐4‐ones using benzoylformates, ketones, and ammonium salts. It incorporates two nitrogen atoms from ammonium salts, forms four CN bonds in one pot, and shows broad substrate compatibility with yields ranging from 24% to 94%, aligning with green chemistry principles.
A catalyst‐ and additive‐free multicomponent reaction is developed for synthesizing substituted 2,3‐dihydro‐4H‐imidazol‐4‐ones from readily available benzoylformates, ketones, and ammonium salts. This protocol features dual nitrogen incorporation from ammonium salts and four CN bonds formation in one pot under optimized conditions. It exhibits broad substrate scope and good functionality tolerance, aligning with green chemistry principles.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: π‐Conjugated 2‐Arylindoles with High Quantum Yields and Tunable Spectroscopic Features
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
New π‐conjugated 2‐arylindole‐based fluorophores bearing (hetero)aryleneethynylene units and a pendant ester group are prepared. These show high fluorescence quantum yields (up to 94%) and solvatochromic effects. The ester moiety allows easy access to other functional groups, such as an N‐hydroxysuccinimide whose reactivity can be exploited for proteins and antibodies bioconjugation.
Indole‐based fluorophores represent a promising class of fluorescent probes due to their tunable optical properties, structural versatility, and compatibility with biological systems. In this work, the design, synthesis, and photophysical characterization of a new series of 2‐arylindole derivatives functionalized with (hetero)aryleneethynylene units and a pendant ester group are reported. The compounds are synthesized via Fischer indole synthesis followed by Sonogashira coupling, enabling also the introduction of electron‐donating (–NMe2) and electron‐withdrawing (–CN) substituents. Furthermore, they are decorated with an N‐hydroxysuccinimidyl (NHS) moiety for facile bioconjugation. Spectroscopic studies conducted in solvents of varying polarity reveal strong solvatochromic effects, high fluorescence quantum yields (up to 94%), and emission wavelengths spanning the blue to green region. Selected derivatives are successfully conjugated to bovine serum albumin, thanks to the NHS reactive group. Photophysical measurements of the resulting protein conjugates reveal that the fluorophores remain solvent‐exposed, maintaining their emission profiles in aqueous media—an important feature for potential bioimaging and sensing applications. These findings highlight the utility of indole‐based scaffolds for the development of environmentally responsive fluorescent probes.
